description: Erection of single storey side extension
decision_conditions: The proposed erection of single storey side extension falls within the parameters of  permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Application Site: 43 Market Place lies on a prominent location on the corner of Market Place, Eden Street and Bath Passage. The curved building  comprises ground  floor with three upper storeys. The property is in restaurant use at ground floor  (Zizzi) Use Class E.The application site is located within Kingston town centre. It is on a secondary shopping frontage. The building is an identified  Building of Townscape Merit within the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area. The site is located within Flood Zone 2. The site is located within a Controlled Parking Zone (CPZ).Proposal: Installation of 3nos. internally illuminated fascia signs, 1no. non-illuminated fascia sign and 2nos. externally illuminated projecting signsConsultation: A total of 13 neighbours were consulted and no response was received. Planning Considerations: The key areas of assessment are:- The impact of the proposal on the character and appearance;- The impact of the proposal on neighbouring residential amenity; and- The impact of the proposal on highway safety. Character and Appearance: National Planning Policy Framework (2023) (NPPF) para 131 states the creation of high-quality, beautiful and sustainable buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve. London Plan (2021) (LP) Policy D8(B) ensures the public realm is well-designed, safe, accessible, inclusive, attractive, well-connected and easy to understand, service and maintain. Lighting, including for advertisements, should be carefully considered and well-designed in order to minimise intrusive lighting infrastructure and reduce light pollution. Core Strategy (2012) (CS) DM10(T) states that advertisements should be avoided where they will be visually intrusive and likely to result in an adverse effect on the character and visual amenities of the local and wider areaOfficer Comment: The proposed development would cause no visual clutter or harm to the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and the proposal would preserve the Kingston Old Town Conservation Area's character. It is considered that the proposed signage would be a sympathetic addition to the host property. Therefore, officers considered the proposed signage to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design.Impact on Residential Amenity:NPPF para 135 sets an expectation that new development will be designed to create places that amongst other things have a 'high standard' of amenity for existing and future users. This is reflected in LP Policy D3. CS Policy DM10 is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The signage is minor and would not be visually obtrusive in terms of light spillage, glare and outlook. The illuminance level would be restricted by condition. Officers do not consider the proposed development would not result in adverse impacts on neighbouring amenity. Highways and Transportation:NPPF para 115 states development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network would be severe. LP Policy T2(b) aims to promote the Mayor's Healthy Streets Approach to improve street safety, comfort, convenience and amenity. CS Policy DM10 seeks to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions and does not contribute to congestion, on street car parking pressure, or compromise pedestrian or highway safety.Officer Comment: Advertisement displays are part of the established street scene and are not an unexpected addition in the road environment. The advertisement is small scale and would have a low illuminance to reduce potential distraction for drivers and pedestrians moving along the road. Officers are satisfied the proposal would not result in an unacceptable harmful effect on the safety and useability of the highway and  public safety, subject to the imposition of conditions. Conclusion:Officers are satisfied the proposal would not result in unacceptable impacts on the character and appearance of the area or the amenity of surrounding occupiers, or an unacceptable risk to public safety. In conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the Development Plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.
